text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section today I'm gonna show you how to
make pumpkin pie do you think I'm gonna
use canned pumpkin no way pumpkin pie
made with fresh pumpkins is so much
better it's worth the effort when I was
coming up with my recipe for pumpkin pie
I tested 9 different varieties of
squashes to see which one is the best I
did a sugar pumpkin a little bit stringy
kabocha too earthy carnival squash tough
took forever to cook Blue Hubbard watery
delicata bland cheese pumpkin granular I
didn't test the crookneck pumpkin
because it was too pretty to cut and so
what's the best butternut squash sweet
tender easy to handle you can peel it
with a vegetable peeler makes a gorgeous
puree you're gonna need a two and a half
to 3 pound
butternut squash peel it cut it up into
you know chunks toss it with a little
bit of oil or melted butter and then
roast it at 400 for about 30 to 45
minutes it needs to be very tender when
the squash is finished it's going to
look like this nice and tender when it's
cool enough to handle you want to puree
it
when it's quite smooth measure out one
and three-quarter cups for the pie and
then if there's any leftover you can
freeze it use it in muffins or pancakes
don't throw it out though it'll come in
handy you can make the squash puree five
days ahead then when you're ready to
bake the pie just combine it in a bowl
with three eggs
hang on egg shell come on egg shell you
know the trick about using a little
piece of eggshell to get the egg shell
out it attracts it for some reason then
you want to add cream brown sugar and
spices for the exact recipe go to
nytimes.com slash dining then just pour
it into your pre baked pie crust
don't buy a pie crust really you can
make it it's not that hard I did another
video he'll show you how to do it you
can find it anyway if you want to bake
your pie crust leave it a little bit
pale you don't want it too golden at
this point because you're gonna rebake
it again with the filling in it this
might not be the prettiest pie crust in
the world but it definitely looks
homemade then bake this at 325 for
forty-five minutes to an hour you know
it's done when you give the pan a little
shake it should be mostly firm with a
slight jiggle right in the center and
there you have it a homemade pumpkin pie
made with fresh pumpkin bragging rights
okay dig in who wants pumpkin pie
